prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: upper sco - group 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum observations in Band 3 of 13 disks in Upper Sco. These have rms of 70 muJy/beam.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are asking for continuum observations and so we chose the "Single Continuum" option as a spectral type mode.

Since the main goal of this project is to determine the total flux density at 2.8 mm we do not want to resolve the dust emission from the disk, and so we ask for the most compact array configuration (C36-1 gives an angular resolution of slightly more than 3 arcsec in Band 3).

As detailed in the text of the proposal, this is the group of the 14 brighter disks in our sample. The continuum sensitivity was chosen to have a SNR of 3 for the faintest disk in this group in the case of a large value of 3.2 for the mm-spectral index (since we know the flux at 0.89mm from our previous measurements with ALMA in Band 7). In the case of lower spectral indices than 3.2 and for the other brighter disks within this group the expected SNR is > 3. We are not interested in studying line emission.

The choice of 105.0 GHz as the "Sky Frequency" will allow us to get better signal to noise (considering the mm-SED of young disks) than would have been possible if choosing the standard frequency instead.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: upper sco - group 2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum observations in Band 3 of 11 disks in Upper Sco. These have rms of 36 muJy/beam.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are asking for continuum observations and so we chose the "Single Continuum" option as a spectral type mode.

Since the main goal of this project is to determine the total flux density at 2.8 mm we do not want to resolve the dust emission from the disk, and so we ask for the most compact array configuration (C36-1 gives an angular resolution of slightly more than 3 arcsec in Band 3).

As detailed in the text of the proposal, this is the group of the 11 fainter disks in our sample. The continuum sensitivity was chosen to have a SNR of 3 for the faintest disk in this group in the case of a large value of 3.2 for the mm-spectral index (since we know the flux at 0.89mm from our previous measurements with ALMA in Band 7). In the case of lower spectral indices than 3.2 and for the other brighter disks within this group the expected SNR is > 3. We are not interested in studying line emission.

The choice of 105.0 GHz as the "Sky Frequency" will allow us to get better signal to noise (considering the mm-SED of young disks) than would have been possible if choosing the standard frequency instead.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe 24 disks in the Upper Sco star forming region at about 3 mm with ALMA in Cycle 3. By combining these observations with the detections obtained for these disks at 0.89 mm, we will measure for the first time the mm-spectral index of disks towards the end of their lifetime, i.e. ~ 5 - 10 Myr. These observations will tell us whether trapping of mm/cm-sized particles, observed in the outer regions of younger disks, occurs also at the end of the disk lifetime, or whether radial drift of these solids takes over a few Myr after the disk birth. This is crucial for our understanding of the formation of planetesimals, and therefore of planets, since it is in these dust traps that planetesimals are expected to form.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Physics Mathematics and Astronomy, California Institute of Technology
